In Philosophy this is relevant to the fallacy of Composition and Division.

Composition - an illicit presumption about the relationship between a whole thing and the parts that make it up, the fallacy is committed when we assume that any property that all of the parts share is also a property of the whole. (If we assume both instance 1 and 2 of vid-con cards being more probable confirms that vid-con cards are more probable)

Division is the reverse where we assume a characteristic of the whole is also shared by the parts.

This paradox bites people all the time when it comes to talking about people. Individual human beings are utterly unpredictable. It is best to never try. On aggregate, however, a group of human beings is fundamentally different from the individuals that make it up, and they are very predictable. This distinction is very, very, very important. This is why you can predict whether there will be crime tomorrow, but NOT whether person X will commit a crime tomorrow. Individual human actions are very largely influenced by an infinite number of random variables. If Mohammed Atta got a bad burrito from a cart on September 8th, 2001, there might not have been a terrorist attack on 9/11. There might never have been one at all. Even if you were Atta himself, you could say what you wanted to do, but you wouldn't have a great success rate if you tried to predict your own actions ahead of time. Far too many things can intervene.

And that's not even getting started on the idea of predicting 'black swan' events with statistics which is just fundamentally not something you can do. This is important because people use statistics to influence you, and because some other people want your permission to do things in your name based on predictive models (if you live in the US... what do you think the NSA does with all that data? They don't read it. They train predictive models... models that might very well predict you'll blow up the world tomorrow.).

For me, the defining characteristics of statistics describes the cosmos rather well and lends to the logical conclusion that the multi-worlds theory must be true. Since every occurrence is equally likely and/or unlikely to take place for any given systemic model, this indicates that all such happenstance(s) must exist simultaneously until observation. Being that the act of observation collapses this wave function, the underlying causality would be the conscious interpretation of relativistic space-time. In this way, the underlying motivating factor of the universe could be described as consciousness itself.
Related to this notion is the concept of the infinite. For instance, it can be said that before the big bang and inflation, time itself did not exist. This is the same as saying that "time" was infinite because our relative definition of space-time is derived from causal observation and without relativistic space-time (and thereby causality) there would exist no scale with which to measure differentiation. On an infinite scale, there is no differentiation either, since all things must come to pass - that being the characteristic of "in"finite. So, before the big bang, the universe was without form and void, thus infinite but that being the case, the infinite could not have had a beginning nor end which leads to the conclusion that the true nature and state of the universe did not change, only that it became consciously observed, which is why we lay claim to the "observable universe".
A similar logical conclusion can be arrived at upon examining Zeno's paradox. Through the use of infinitesimals we can show that no motion can ever actually take place. If instead, we assume that there are no local points in space-time (and thereby individual particles), then the paradox solves itself because it is immediately clear that everything can be describe as existing in a single point. You don't actually move, you are already there because there are no separate particles. It is then a simple matter to realize that every "thing" is merely a part of the whole of the universe itself, rather than separated. Going back to the idea that conscious observation is required for causality and that the observable universe is a continuation of the infinite reality, it then seems apparent that there is an infinite consciousness of which we are merely parts, akin to cells of our body.

Haven't seen the last one where Henry made Hank "feel like an idiot", but I think that "being made to feel like an idiot" can be one of the greatest gifts you can give an open-minded person (if done properly, that is*) : Because it means there is something you don't know, something new you can learn. And, unlike a simple "a-ha" way of realizing that, the "feeling like an idiot" way means that this is something new to learn in an area where you didn't expect it. And while this might feel uncomfortable in the moment, I think the result is still beautiful.

*That is of course if you're not just like "Ha-ha, I know something you don't and that makes you an idiot!", which I'm just gonna assume wasn't the case here ;)

What happens when you apply statistics to the "many worlds" theory? Couldn't it mean that the future is both finite and knowable? For instance, for any given outcome, a finite set of experiences led to it. There may be an infinite-seeming set of possible futures from this point, but there was an infinite set of possible choices that led to the present we experience, and there will be a finite set of choices to each present that we inhabit. Certainly some futures will be statistically more likely than others. I'm not about to sprout wings, for instance, but that doesn't mean that there couldn't be a timeline in which evolution took a decidedly different track.

Given that my life is finite and at the end of my life there will have been only one set of decisions that led me to that end, could there be a "formula" of sorts that could accurately predict reality as I will experience it? ("No", while a perfectly valid answer, is deeply unsatisfying...)

The overall acceptance rate depends on what department they apply to.  Suppose all of the men apply to the film department and none to ornithology.   Then the overall acceptance rate would be 33%.  But if all the men applied to the ornithology department, the rate would be 50%.  If they apply to both departments, it is somewhere in between.  THERE IS NO PARADOX!

One time I was thinking about how in science, the more you do something and get certain results, the more likely you are to continue getting those results. But with a deck of cards, the more aces you pull out, the LESS likely you are to pull out another ace (at least until you get to five and then you realize that something is amiss). Then I thought, what if science is actually like a huge deck of cards, and we're doing it backwards? Not actually a realistic thought, but it was interesting to me at the time.

Huh. This actually happens in voting, where the popular vote goes for one candidate, but the electoral vote goes toward the other. Say candidate A barely wins in many states, while in the few he loses, almost the entire vote goes against him, creating a popular bias for candidate B, with candidate A winning on a state by state basis, winning the vote overall.

Just to clarify, the quantum causality math was developed decades before the discovery that classical causality math fails. The Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen paradox was not long after the development of Schrordinger's Wave Mechanics and Heisenberg's Matrix Mechanics (which were later discovered to be the same thing in different forms). But Bell's Theorem that shows why Einstein's view of the paradox was wrong wasn't until about 30 years later.

Quantum Mechanics is explained by the Scale of Observation. Entanglement is the resonance of energy at the lowest possible Observable Scale. The reason both spins always line up instantly, is because of an underlying constant. This constant is the boundary of energy transmission.

For every possible Scale of Observation there is a corresponding measure of Energy. Because of this, it can be assumed that beyond the uppermost and lower most boundaries of Energy transmission, there exist geometrically similar expressions of physical forces. Basically, every bubble on the string with Energy being transmitted, is its own isolated Universe with its own physical forces.

Because the Universe is made of Energy. And Energy is infinitely divisible by wavelength. This is how you make infinity.

These are weak. They aren't paradoxes. It's more like sleight of hand. The truly "weird" things come from more probabilistic things, such as the St. Petersburg Paradox.

The causal thing near the beginning also irked me. Saying that the distribution "causes" an event or proc is a naive interpretation. That would be like saying the distribution of temperature across the globe causes hot air. No, it describes hot air distribution across a landmass. The fact that the surface of the Earth is not uniformly the same in temperature does not causes the non-uniformity in temperature. Likewise, the fact that the base rates of the subpopulations of applicants are not uniform across subjects does not cause a different output.

I'd like to coin the term "influence" in a paper if I ever get published because while the fact that the earth is non uniform in temperature does not cause the various kinds of temperatures, if I or another thing were to impose a change on the distribution, a change in temperature in areas would occur and we would reasonable call that a causation: I caused a change in temperature.

"Causation" is a philosophical subject that really shouldn't be touched by statisticians except in the strictest of mathematical sense. "Influence" just means "if I change X, Y will change" as opposed to the weaker 'correlation' which is just observing intersections of variation in a glorified Venn diagram.

I agree with you guys about everyone should understand statistics and probability more. Especially fallacies, errors, and just the fact that experiments, especially in social science fields, can just be poorly designed where statistics can be significant or not significant when the reality is the opposite, not because of a paradox but because of poor experimental design, which I think happens far more than paradoxes. Small sample size, poor sample selection, introduction of third variables, etc etc. I think it's important for people to not just read the stat, but read how it was found to determine the limitations of it. But average everyday people just can't do that, or don't have access to it. But politicians and scientists who are making decisions based off these statistics NEED to do this rigorously.

This hypothetical you use about more or less women are CHOOSING to enter or not enter certain fields is what most detractors of 3rd wave feminists are actually seeing in real statistics. Many of these feminists are stating as the conclusive fact is "there are less women in the STEM subjects; therefore sexism." Most of the arguments that I've heard from their detractors is that this is simply not true. The statistics, when being throughly analyzed, are revealing there are less women in the STEM subjects is due to that less women are choosing to enter those fields.
